contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox cyclist | name = Rolf Aldag | image = Rolf Aldag Gaillac.jpg | caption = Rolf Aldag, individual time trial Tour de France 2003 | fullname = Rolf Aldag | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|8|25}} | birth_place = [[Beckum, Germany|Beckum]], [[Germany]] | currentteam = {{ct|THR}} | discipline = Road | role = Directeur sportif | ridertype = | amateuryears = | amateurteams = | proyears = 1991–1992<br />1993–2005 | proteams = Helvetia<br />{{ct|THR|1993}} | manageyears = 2006– | manageteams = {{ct|THR|2006}} | majorwins = {{flagicon|Germany}} National Champion (2000) | updated = July 8, 2009 }} '''Rolf Aldag''' (born 25 August 1968 in [[Beckum, Germany]]) is a former professional [[road bicycle racer]] who rode for [[Team Telekom]] from 1993 to 2005. He raced in 10 [[Tour de France]], 1 [[Giro d'Italia]] and 5 [[Vuelta a España]]. Prior to joining Telekom, he raced with [[Helvetia]]. == Career == His career highlights include third stage place in both the 1994 and 1995 Tour de France, a stage win in the [[Tour de Limousin]] in 1996, a stage win in the [[Tour de Suisse]] 1997, overall win of the [[Bayern-Rundfahrt]] in 1999, a stage win in the [[Deutschland Tour]] 1999, being the German road Champion in 2000, a stage win Deutschland Tour 2001, a stage win in the Bayern-Rundfahrt 2002, a 2nd stage place in the [[2003 Tour de France]], winner of the Sparkassen-Giro Bochum in 2003, and winner of the Sparkassen Cup Unna in 2003. Aldag featured in the film [[Hell on Wheels (2004 film)|''Hell on Wheels'']] concerning the 2003 Tour de France. In "retirement", Aldag has set a goal of competing in Ironman triathlons. His first training goal was to complete a marathon in 2 hours 40 minutes. He finished the Hamburg marathon in April 2006 with a time of 2 hours 42 minutes. He went on to finish the 2006 Ironman Lanzarote triathlon in the Canary Islands in 50th place of 825 finishers with a total time of 10:22:14 (swim 1:23:18, bike 5:18:05, run 3:27:56). T-Mobile hired Aldag as sporting director after sacking [[Rudy Pevenage]] who was named in the 2006 [[Operación Puerto doping case]]. Aldag managed the team up the end of 2011 when {{ct|THR}} folded due to lack of sponsorship.<ref>http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/aldag-blasts-uci-mcquaid-and-pro-cycling</ref> == Doping Confession == On 24 May 2007 Aldag together with former Team Telekom team mate and personal friend [[Erik Zabel]] admitted having used [[Erythropoietin]] (EPO) from 1995 to 1999. Aldag also publicly apologized for having lied about his use of EPO in the past.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/news.php?id=news/2007/may07/may24news2 |title=Zabel and Aldag confess EPO usage |date=2007-05-24 |accessdate=2007-05-24 |work=cyclingnews.com |first=Susan |last=Westemeyer}}</ref> His confession was triggered by accusations of former Team Telekom masseur [[Jef d'Hont]] from Belgium. In his book, of which excerpts where printed in the German political magazine [[Der Spiegel]] in April 2007, D'Hont accused members of Team Telekom of systematic and organized doping with EPO in the mid-1990s.<ref name="DS-2007-04-28">[http://www.spiegel.de/sport/sonst/0,1518,480042,00.html Masseur wirft Team Telekom systematisches Doping vor] Der Spiegel, 28 April 2007 (German)</ref> ==See also== * [[List of doping cases in cycling]] *[[List of sportspeople sanctioned for doping offences]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=176116038}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Aldag, Rolf | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = German racing cyclist | DATE OF BIRTH = 1968-08-25 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Beckum, Germany | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aldag, Rolf}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Warendorf (district)]] [[Category:German cyclists]] [[Category:German cycling road race champions]] [[Category:Cyclists at the 1996 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic cyclists of Germany]] [[Category:Doping cases in cycling]] [[Category:Tour de Suisse stage winners]]
